words.definition: Present, appearing, or found everywhere.
examples: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society.
The ubiquitous coffee shops made finding caffeine easy.

words.definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically based on practical considerations.
examples: She took a pragmatic approach to solving the budget crisis.
His pragmatic nature helped him succeed in business.
distractors: Characterized by rigid adherence to rules.

words.definition: Well-meaning and kindly; showing goodwill.
examples: The benevolent donor gave millions to charity.
Her benevolent smile put everyone at ease.
distractors: Indifferent to the needs of others.

words.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
examples: The ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms draws crowds each spring.
Fame can be ephemeral in the age of social media.
distractors: Related to ethereal or spiritual matters.

words.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; ambiguous.
examples: The politician gave an equivocal answer to avoid controversy.
The evidence was equivocal and could support either conclusion.

words.definition: Having mixed feelings or contradictory ideas about something.
examples: She felt ambivalent about moving to a new city.
His ambivalent response suggested he hadn't made up his mind.

words.definition: Fluent or persuasive in speaking or writing.
examples: The lawyer delivered an eloquent closing argument.
Her eloquent essay moved the judges to tears.

words.definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
examples: The meticulous accountant found every discrepancy.
She was meticulous in planning the wedding details.
distractors: Focused only on the big picture.

words.definition: Able to recover quickly from difficulties; tough.
examples: The resilient community rebuilt after the hurricane.
Children are often more resilient than adults realize.
distractors: Resistant to all forms of change.

words.definition: Holding firmly to something; persistent and determined.
examples: The tenacious reporter wouldn't give up on the story.
Her tenacious grip on the rope saved her life.

words.definition: Abundant in supply or quantity.
examples: She took copious notes during the lecture.
The garden produced copious amounts of vegetables.

words.definition: Involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
examples: The arduous climb to the summit took eight hours.
Learning a new language is an arduous but rewarding task.

words.definition: Truthful and straightforward; frank.
examples: The CEO was candid about the company's challenges.
Her candid photographs captured genuine emotions.

words.definition: Having or showing care and conscientiousness in work or duties.
examples: The diligent student always completed assignments early.
Diligent research uncovered the historical truth.

words.definition: Having or displaying passionate intensity.
examples: She was a fervent supporter of environmental causes.
His fervent speech inspired the crowd.

words.definition: Fond of company; sociable.
examples: The gregarious host made everyone feel welcome.
Dolphins are known for their gregarious behavior.

words.definition: Lacking any obvious principle of organization.
examples: The books were arranged in a haphazard manner.
His haphazard approach to planning caused problems.

words.definition: Continuing without pause or interruption.
examples: The incessant rain lasted for three days.
Her incessant complaining annoyed everyone.

words.definition: Having, showing, or done with good judgment or sense.
examples: A judicious use of resources prevented waste.
The judicious manager considered all perspectives.

words.definition: Expressed clearly; easy to understand.
examples: His lucid explanation made the concept clear.
She remained lucid despite her illness.

words.definition: Lacking interest or excitement; dull and ordinary.
examples: She longed for adventure to escape her mundane routine.
Even mundane tasks require attention to detail.

words.definition: Feeling or appearing casually calm and relaxed.
examples: He gave a nonchalant shrug when asked about his success.
Her nonchalant attitude hid her nervousness.

words.definition: Not discovered or known about; uncertain.
examples: The artist remained obscure until after her death.
The meaning of the ancient text is obscure.

words.definition: Very great or intense; having deep insight.
examples: The book had a profound impact on her worldview.
He made a profound observation about human nature.

words.definition: Attractively unusual or old-fashioned.
examples: The quaint village attracted many tourists.
She lived in a quaint cottage by the sea.

words.definition: Strong and healthy; vigorous.
examples: The robust economy showed strong growth.
Despite his age, he remained robust and active.

words.definition: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
examples: The report contained superfluous details.
His apology seemed superfluous after her forgiveness.

words.definition: Reserved or uncommunicative in speech; saying little.
examples: The taciturn farmer spoke only when necessary.
She became taciturn after hearing the bad news.

words.definition: Liable to change rapidly and unpredictably.
examples: The stock market has been volatile this year.
His volatile temper made him unpredictable.

words.definition: Having or showing great enthusiasm and energy.
examples: The zealous volunteers worked through the night.
She was zealous in defending her beliefs.
